articles.title: SJAA Officers
articles.summary: This document lists the current officers and board members of the SJAA (San Jose Astronomical Association), including contact information for key positions. It also contains an administrative note informing members that the current issue was mailed early due to a change in the date and location of the monthly public star party, advising them to check the "coming events" section for details.

articles.title: RECENT ACTIVITIES:
articles.summary: The article details two recent club activities: a September 6th meeting and a September 14th star party. The meeting featured a discussion on club speakers and a talk by Jim Vermilion on Europa's surface features, while the star party at Skyline was hampered by damp weather, though some members found success observing and imaging at the Coe site. Consequently, there is a strong recommendation to adopt Henry Coe State Park as the new regular star party location due to its better conditions.

articles.title: COMING EVENTS:
articles.summary: This document outlines a series of upcoming astronomical events for a club or organization, primarily in the San Jose area. It includes public star parties, general meetings featuring equipment/slides and a guest speaker, and an overnight star party. The document also notes a change in venue for general meetings starting in November and provides directions.

articles.title: NEWS NOTES:
articles.summary: Members of the club attended an impromptu star party at Coe on September 21, enjoying excellent views of Jupiter, including a rare satellite shadow transit and the Great Red Spot, along with various deep-sky objects like globular clusters M15 and M56, the Veil and Crab nebulae, and several Auriga clusters. The report also includes technical notes providing predicted October times for Jupiter's Red Spot meridian crossings and solar central meridian dates, plus a mention of an upcoming Messier Catalog arrangement.

articles.title: The Messier Catalog
articles.summary: This document presents a portion of The Messier Catalog, listing various astronomical deep-sky objects with their NGC designations, celestial coordinates (Right Ascension and Declination), associated constellations, magnitudes, types (e.g., galaxies, nebulae, star clusters), sizes, and brief descriptions. The catalog provides essential observational data for identifying and locating these objects, likely serving as a guide for amateur astronomers.
